dt: {bc}unlawful sexual activity and usually sexual intercourse carried out forcibly or under threat of injury against a person's will or with a person who is beneath a certain age or incapable of valid consent because of mental illness, mental deficiency, intoxication, unconsciousness, or deception {dx}compare {dxt|sexual assault||}, {dxt|statutory rape||}{/dx}
{bc}an act or instance of robbing or despoiling or carrying away a person by force

et: Middle English, "violent seizure, abduction of a woman with the intent of sexually assaulting her," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}rap, rape,{/it} probably borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}rapum,{/it} noun derivative of {it}rapiō, rapere{/it} "to seize and carry off, abduct a woman with the intent of sexually assaulting her" {ma}{mat|rape:2|}{/ma}

Use of this word in its most predominant modern meaning is attested early in legal Anglo-French and British Medieval Latin, though the precise derivational pathways are uncertain. The Latin word may have been based on the Anglo-French word, but both must ultimately be dependent on the classical Latin verb. Note that {it}rapum{/it} exists alongside classical Latin {it}raptus,{/it} the regularly derived u-stem verbal noun, used in British Medieval Latin in the sense "rape." Compare {et_link|ravish|ravish}.
shortdef: unlawful sexual activity and usually sexual intercourse carried out forcibly or under threat of injury against a person's will or with a person who is beneath a certain age or incapable of valid consent because of mental illness, mental deficiency, intoxication, unconsciousness, or deception
an act or instance of robbing or despoiling or carrying away a person by force

dt: {bc}to seize and take away by force

et: Middle English {it}rapen{/it} "to abduct a woman with the intent of sexually assaulting her," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}raper,{/it} borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}rapiō, rapere{/it} "to seize and carry off, abduct a woman with of the intent of sexually assaulting her," going back to Latin, "to seize and carry off, take away by force, carry off a woman with the intent of sexually assaulting her, carry or sweep along, impel forcibly (to a course of conduct), snatch up, gather quickly" {ma}{mat|rapid:1|}{/ma}

The verb {it}rapen{/it} in its predominant modern sense is rare in Middle English, the more common verb meaning "to rape" being {it}ravisshen{/it} "to {et_link|ravish|ravish}." The {it}Middle English Dictionary{/it} lists {it}rapen{/it} with a meaning "to carry off, transport (the soul to heaven)," but all forms cited are for a past participle {it}rapt, rapte,{/it} which appears to have been borrowed directly from Medieval Latin {it}raptus,{/it} past participle of {it}rapere{/it} in this sense (see {et_link|rapt|rapt}). See also the note at {et_link|rape:1|rape:1}.
shortdef: to seize and take away by force

dt: {bc}an Old World herb ({it}Brassica napus{/it}) of the mustard family grown as a forage crop and for its seeds which yield {a_link|rapeseed} oil and are a bird food {dx}compare {dxt|canola||}{/dx}

et: Middle English, "turnip, {it}Brassica napus{/it}," borrowed from Latin {it}rāpa, rāpum{/it} "turnip"; akin to Germanic {it}*rōbjōn-{/it} "turnip" (whence Middle Dutch & Middle Low German {it}rove{/it}, Old High German {it}ruoba, ruoppa{/it}), Lithuanian {it}rópė{/it}, Greek {it}rháphys, rhápys{/it} (all going back to an earlier {it}*rāp(h)-{/it}), Church Slavic (eastern) {it}rěpa{/it}, Polish {it}rzepa{/it} (going back to {it}*rēp-{/it}), Welsh {it}erfin{/it} "turnips, rape," Breton {it}irvin{/it} (going back to {it}*arb-īno-{/it}, perhaps metathesized from {it}*rab-{/it}), all from a substratal pre-Indo-European word of uncertain form

The Greek forms with fluctuating aspiration, as well as the derivative {it}rháphanos{/it} {ldquo}any of various cultivars of {it}Brassica oleracea,{/it} radish,{rdquo} with the suffix {it}-anos,{/it} argue for membership in the same pre-Greek substratum as a number of other Greek words; whether the other European forms are borrowed from this etymon or are part of a more general substratum is unclear (see Robert Beekes, {it}Etymological Dictionary of Greek,{/it} Brill, 2010, p. 1277). Not related to Old Norse {it}rófa{/it} {ldquo}tail{rdquo} (see Guus Kroonen, {it}Etymological Dictionary of Proto-Germanic,{/it} Brill, 2013, p. 415).
shortdef: an Old World herb (Brassica napus) of the mustard family grown as a forage crop and for its seeds which yield rapeseed oil and are a bird food

dt: {bc}the {d_link|pomace|pomace} of grapes left after expression of the juice

shortdef: the pomace of grapes left after expression of the juice

rape committed by the victim's date; broadly : acquaintance rape
